narrative.title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan

question.text: Types and amount of scientific data expected to be generated in the project

json.answer: The project aims to investigate anxiety symptoms and resilience processes in adolescents using longitudinal behavioral, clinical, and neurobiological assessments. The types of scientific data expected to be generated include demographic and clinical datasets, standardized anxiety and resilience scales, behavioral task data, physiological measures (e.g., heart rate variability), and derived summary variables. The estimated amount of scientific data is substantial due to the longitudinal multi-modal nature of the study, with physiological data and raw task files representing the largest portion of storage.

question.text: Scientific data that will be preserved and shared, and the rationale for doing so

json.answer: All collected data will be preserved and shared in a de-identified manner, consistent with the informed consent provided by participants. This includes demographic and clinical datasets, behavioral task data, physiological measures, and derived summary variables. The rationale for sharing these data is to facilitate further research into adolescent mental health, anxiety, and resilience mechanisms, thereby contributing to the development of more effective interventions.

question.text: Metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation

json.answer: To facilitate interpretation of the scientific data, the following metadata will be shared: study protocol, informed consent documents, data dictionary, and a README file explaining the structure and content of the datasets. Additionally, survey tools and code used in the project can be accessed through a DOI (e.g., 10.5281/zenodo.7449282), and relevant documentation will be posted to ClinicalTrials.gov.

section.title: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

question.text: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

json.answer: Specialized tools and software needed to access or manipulate shared scientific data include statistical analysis packages (e.g., R, Python) for handling demographic and clinical datasets, behavioral task data, and physiological measures. These tools can be accessed through their respective websites or academic licenses.

The project will apply common data standards to enable interoperability of datasets and resources. Specifically, the data will be formatted according to the National Institutes of Health (NIH) guidelines for data sharing, including the use of standardized data dictionaries and metadata formats. For physiological data, standards from the PhysioNet platform will be followed. If applicable, adherence to specific standards for behavioral task data and clinical assessments will also be ensured.

section.title: Element 4: Data Preservation, Access, and Associated Timelines

question.text: Repository where scientific data and metadata will be archived

json.answer: The scientific data and metadata arising from the project will be archived in a designated NIH-approved repository (e.g., National Institute of Mental Health Data Archive), ensuring long-term preservation and accessibility.

question.text: How scientific data will be findable and identifiable

json.answer: Scientific data will be made findable and identifiable through persistent unique identifiers (e.g., DOIs) and standard indexing tools, facilitating easy access and citation by other researchers.

question.text: When and how long the scientific data will be made available

json.answer: The scientific data will be made available as soon as possible but no later than the time of an associated publication or the end of the performance period, whichever comes first. The duration of preservation and sharing of the data will be permanent, ensuring that the data remain accessible for future research.

section.title: Element 5: Access, Distribution, or Reuse Considerations

question.text: Factors affecting subsequent access, distribution, or reuse of scientific data

json.answer: Factors affecting subsequent access include the need to protect participant privacy and confidentiality. Data use limitations are primarily related to the informed consent provided by participants, which allows for de-identified data sharing for research purposes.

question.text: Whether access to scientific data will be controlled

json.answer: Access to the scientific data will be controlled through a designated data repository, requiring approval for access to ensure compliance with privacy and confidentiality protections.

question.text: Protections for privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants

json.answer: To protect the privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants, all shared data will be de-identified. The project has obtained broad consent from participants for de-identified data sharing, and an IRB review has verified that the submission of data to the NIH data repository is consistent with the informed consent.

section.title: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

question.text: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

json.answer: Compliance with this Plan will be monitored and managed by the Principal Investigator (PI) and the research institution's data management office. Regular checks will ensure that all shared data are properly de-identified, that access controls are in place, and that sharing is conducted according to the approved plan. The frequency of oversight will be at least quarterly during active data collection phases and annually thereafter. This oversight structure ensures adherence to NIH guidelines for data management and sharing while protecting participant confidentiality and promoting open scientific inquiry.
